thread.title: Labour MP claims her husband has been targeted as council calls him 'perpetrator of elder abuse'

title: Labour MP claims her husband has been targeted as council calls him 'perpetrator of elder abuse'

A Labour MP says she has been victimised because of action her local council has taken against her husband. 
Emma Lewell-Buck , Labour MP for South Shields, said: “It’s not pleasant but I’m not going to just sit here and neither is my husband.” 
South Tyneside Council is to debate findings published by the Local Government and Social Care Ombudsman, which criticise the way the authority conducted an investigation into Mrs Lewell-Buck’s husband, Simon Buck, a care worker. 
The Ombudsman report calls on the council to apologise, and to pay Mr Buck £400 “to recognise the impact of avoidable delay, distress, uncertainty and time and trouble caused by the faults identified in this report”. 
It follows claims, denied by Mr Buck, that he was abusive towards two vulnerable adults receiving care. In one case, he was said to have sworn at an a vulnerable adult and his wife. 
In the second, he was said to have sworn at a vulnerable adult and wrongly said the man’s incontinence pad was clean. 
Investigations by the council concluded these accusations were true. However, the Ombudsman has criticised the council for failing to follow its procedures properly. Read More New report on the Heathrow Airport expansion plans - but it's calling for MORE delays 
For example, the Ombudsman found the council appointed an independent social worker to look into one of the complaints - and the social worker “concluded there was no evidence that abuse occurred”. 
The council was meant to share the conclusions with Mr Buck at least five days in advance of a hearing to examine the allegations, and failed to do so. 
Michael King, of the Local Government and Social Care Ombudsman, said: “People have a right to be treated fairly during any investigation, and that includes having access to any reports written about them before crucial meetings take place.” 
Rather than accept the recommendations to apologise and pay Mr Buck compensation, the authority will instead decide what to do at a full council meeting on Monday. 
And it appears reluctant agree to the findings, saying in a statement it is “concerned that the council has been asked to make a payment of compensation to a perpetrator of elder abuse”. South Shields Town Hall (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Mrs Lewell-Buck said: “I find it very bizarre. I was a local councillor myself for 20 years and not once did we debate an Ombudsman’s report.” 
She pointed out the report simply referred to her husband as “Mr Y”, but his full identity had become known to the local media. 
“Simon’s name and the name of the other parties were not published, but his name had clearly been leaked to a newspaper.” 
She claims her husband had been unfairly targeted. 
“What better way to get at the MP than to destroy her husband,” she said. 
Mr Buck said: “I cannot begin to describe the stress of the past couple of years since these allegations appeared out of the blue, aimed at discrediting me. 
“I flatly deny all of them and note that not a shred of evidence has been produced beyond hearsay to stand any of them up.” 
He added: “I have had to watch as my wife, who is a really hardworking and dedicated local MP, has struggled to deal with the torrent of attacks and attempts to undermine her which come from this council.” Read More Fury over decision to manufacture post-Brexit blue passports in France - what our MPs are saying Here is the full statement from South Tyneside Council: 
A spokesperson for South Tyneside Council said: “South Tyneside Council accepts the Local Government and Social Care Ombudsman findings of minor administrative failing in this case where the council was acting as the administering body for investigations into the abuse of vulnerable people. 
“The Ombudsman has not however challenged the decision made by a panel of multi-agency professionals to uphold a finding of abuse by Mr Y and there is no further challenge to this decision. 
“We are therefore concerned that the council has been asked to make a payment of compensation to a perpetrator of elder abuse. 
“In this case, the Council was unable to demonstrate from the historical electronic care records, that it had shared a report in a specific timeframe, even though it could demonstrate that the complainant was given an opportunity to present his views and challenge the facts in person. 
“We will remind staff of the importance of documenting actions taken and making clear records of the reasons for decisions made by professionals and communicating those in a timely manner. 
“As required by the Ombudsman, the recommendations in his report will be considered at a meeting of Borough Council on Monday 26th March 2018. 
“The Ombudsman’s report on this case is available online and copies are available from South Shields Town Hall, Hebburn Central and Jarrow Town Hall.” Like us on Facebook
